And Rabbi Yochanan said: Even if you were to say the Rabbis, until here the Rabbis did not say there, except regarding the matter of impurity, but here, because it is a matter of his personal opinion, and this does not establish his opinion.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אָכַל וְשָׁתָה בְּהֶעְלֵם אֶחָד — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא חַטָּאת אַחַת. אָכַל וְעָשָׂה מְלָאכָה — חַיָּיב שְׁתֵּי חַטָּאוֹת. אָכַל אוֹכָלִין שֶׁאֵינָן רְאוּיִן לַאֲכִילָה, וְשָׁתָה מַשְׁקִין שֶׁאֵינָן רְאוּיִן לִשְׁתִיָּה, וְשָׁתָה צִיר אוֹ מוּרְיָיס — פָּטוּר.
human_translation: one ate and drank within one lapse of awareness, he is liable only one sin-offering. he ate and performed labor he is liable to bring two sin-offerings, he ate foods that are not fit for eating, or drank liquids that are not fit for drinking, or drank brine or liquid he is exempt,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If one ate and drank in one forgetfulness - he is only liable for one sin offering. If he ate and performed labor - he is liable for two sin offerings. If he ate non-kosher foods, and drank beverages that are not fit for drinking, and he drank vinegar or fish brine - he is exempt.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: מִפְּנֵי מָה לֹא נֶאֶמְרָה אַזְהָרָה בְּעִינּוּי? מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא אֶפְשָׁר. הֵיכִי נִכְתּוֹב? נִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״לֹא יֵאָכֵל״ — אֲכִילָה בִּכְזַיִת! נִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״לֹא תְעוּנֶּה״ — קוּם אֱכוֹל מַשְׁמַע.
human_translation: Reish Lakish said: Why is there no warning stated about affliction; because it was not possible How could write it? Let the Merciful One write: One shall not eat eating the amount of an olive-bulk, Let the Merciful One write: Do not be afflicted. mean: Get up and eat.
llm_translation: Gemara said Reish Lakish: Why was a warning not stated regarding eating in secret? Because it is not possible. How should it be written? It should be written: The Merciful One said, "Do not eat" - eating in secret! The Merciful One said, "Do not oppress" - get up and eat, it is implied.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב הוֹשַׁעְיָא: נִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״הִשָּׁמֶר פֶּן לֹא תְעוּנֶּה״! אִם כֵּן נְפִישִׁי לְהוּ לָאוֵי.
human_translation: Rav Hoshaya strongly objects to this: Let the Merciful One write Guard yourself lest you not be afflicted. If so, there would be many negative mitzvot,
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: Rav Hoshaya objects to her: It is written, "Beware lest you entertain the thought"! If so, should it not be more stringent?

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב בִּיבִי בַּר אַבָּיֵי: נִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״הִשָּׁמֶר בְּמִצְוַת עִינּוּי״! אִם כֵּן ״הִשָּׁמֶר״ דְּלָאו — לָאו, ״הִשָּׁמֶר״ דַּעֲשֵׂה — עֲשֵׂה! מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב אָשֵׁי: נִכְתּוֹב: ״אַל תָּסוּר מִן הָעִינּוּי״! קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: Rav Beivai bar Abaye strongly objects to this: Let the Merciful One write: Guard yourself in the mitzva of affliction. If so, guard yourself about a prohibition, a prohibition; guard yourself about a positive mitzva, a positive mitzva. Rav Ashi strongly objects to this: Let the Merciful One write: Do not stray from afflicting yourself, difficult.
llm_translation: The Gemara challenges Rav Bibi, son of Abbaye: It is written, "Heed the command of affliction"! If so, "heed" that is not a negative command — is not a negative command, "heed" that is a positive command — is a positive command! Rav Ashe challenges him: It is written, "Do not turn away from affliction"! This is difficult.

hebrew_text: וְתַנָּא מַיְיתֵי לַהּ מֵהָכָא: ״וְעִנִּיתֶם אֶת נַפְשׁוֹתֵיכֶם וְכׇל מְלָאכָה לֹא תַעֲשׂוּ״. יָכוֹל יְהֵא עָנוּשׁ עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת מְלָאכָה — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְכׇל הַנֶּפֶשׁ אֲשֶׁר תַּעֲשֶׂה כׇּל מְלָאכָה בְּעֶצֶם הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה״ — עַל עִיצּוּמוֹ שֶׁל יוֹם עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת, וְאֵינוֹ עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת מְלָאכָה.
human_translation: And a tanna cites from here: “And you shall afflict your souls, you shall do no manner of labor” might extension of labor, is punishable the verse states: “And whatsoever soul it be that does any manner of labor on that same day” on that very day is punishable by karet , but the extension of labor is not punishable by karet .
llm_translation: The text states: "And it was taught to her from here: 'And you shall afflict your souls, and you shall not do any work.'" One might have thought that there is a punishment for additional work - the Talmud teaches: "And any soul that does any work on that very day" - there is a punishment of excision for the primary work of the day, but there is no punishment of excision for additional work.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל לֹא יְהֵא עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת מְלָאכָה, אֲבָל יְהֵא עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת עִינּוּי — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי כׇל הַנֶּפֶשׁ אֲשֶׁר לֹא תְעוּנֶּה בְּעֶצֶם הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה וְנִכְרְתָה״. עַל עִיצּוּמוֹ שֶׁל יוֹם עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת, וְאֵינוֹ עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת עִינּוּי.
human_translation: might extension of labor is not punishable by karet , extension of affliction is punishable by karet . the verse states: “For whatsoever soul it be that shall not be afflicted on that same day, he shall be cut off on that very day punishable by karet , but the extension of affliction is not punishable by karet .
llm_translation: One might have thought that there should not be a punishment of excision for additional work, but there should be a punishment of excision for additional affliction - the Talmud teaches: "For any soul that will not afflict itself on that very day shall be cut off." For the essence of the day is the punishment of excision, and there is no punishment of excision for additional affliction.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל לֹא יְהֵא בִּכְלַל עוֹנֶשׁ, אֲבָל יְהֵא מוּזְהָר עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת מְלָאכָה — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְכׇל מְלָאכָה לֹא תַעֲשׂוּ בְּעֶצֶם הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה״. עַל עִיצּוּמוֹ שֶׁל יוֹם הוּא מוּזְהָר, וְאֵינוֹ מוּזְהָר עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת מְלָאכָה.
human_translation: might that not be included in the punishment but he would be warned against extension of labor the verse states: “And you shall do no manner of labor on that same day” he is warned that very day, he is not warned against extension of labor,
llm_translation: One might have thought that it should not be subject to punishment, but one should be warned against additional work - the Talmud teaches: "And no work shall be done on that very day." One should be warned against the onset of the day, but not against additional work.

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל לֹא יְהֵא מוּזְהָר עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת מְלָאכָה, אֲבָל יְהֵא מוּזְהָר עַל תּוֹסֶפֶת עִינּוּי — וְדִין הוּא: וּמָה מְלָאכָה שֶׁנּוֹהֶגֶת בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וְיוֹם טוֹב אֵינוֹ מוּזְהָר עָלֶיהָ, עִינּוּי, שֶׁאֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וְיוֹם טוֹב — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא מוּזְהָר עָלָיו?!
human_translation: might He would not be warned with regard to extension of labor but he would be warned with regard to extension of affliction and a logical derivation Just as labor, whose is observed on Shabbatot and Festivals, one is not warned about is it not logical that affliction, which is not observed on Shabbatot and Festivals, he should not be warned about
llm_translation: One might have thought that one should not be cautious regarding additional work, but one should be cautious regarding additional suffering - and this is the law: And what is considered work that is common on Sabbaths and festivals, one is not cautious about it, but suffering, that is not common on Sabbaths and festivals - is it not the law that one should not be cautious about it?!

hebrew_text: אֲבָל אַזְהָרָה לְעִינּוּי שֶׁל יוֹם עַצְמוֹ לֹא לָמַדְנוּ מִנַּיִין. לֹא יֹאמַר עוֹנֶשׁ בִּמְלָאכָה, דְּגָמַר מֵעִינּוּי: וּמָה עִינּוּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וְיוֹם טוֹב עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת, מְלָאכָה שֶׁנּוֹהֶגֶת בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וְיָמִים טוֹבִים — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן? לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר — מוּפְנֶה לְהַקִּישׁ וְלָדוּן מִמֶּנּוּ גְּזֵרָה שָׁוָה: נֶאֱמַר עוֹנֶשׁ בְּעִינּוּי וְנֶאֱמַר עוֹנֶשׁ בִּמְלָאכָה, מָה מְלָאכָה — לֹא עָנַשׁ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן הִזְהִיר, אַף עִינּוּי — לֹא עָנַשׁ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן הִזְהִיר.
human_translation: But the warning during the very day itself we have not learned. From where need not state the punishment labor, since one can learn it from affliction, Just as affliction, which is not observed on Shabbatot and Festivals, is punishable by karet labor, which is observed on Shabbatot and Festivals, not all the more so? why stated It is available to compare and learn a verbal analogy from it: A punishment affliction is stated, and a punishment labor is stated. Just as labor one is punished only if he was warned so too, affliction, one is punished only if he was warned.
llm_translation: However, a warning for the prohibition of eye affliction on its own, we did not learn from where. One should not say punishment for work, for we learn from eye affliction: And what eye affliction that one does not observe on Sabbaths and festivals is punished with excision, work that is observed on Sabbaths and festivals — is it not all the more so? Why is it stated — to establish a comparison and to deduce a similar decree from it: It is stated punishment for eye affliction and it is stated punishment for work, just as work — is not punished unless one was warned, so too eye affliction — is not punished unless one was warned.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא לְמִיפְרַךְ: מָה לְעִינּוּי שֶׁלֹּא הוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ, תֹּאמַר בִּמְלָאכָה שֶׁהוּתְּרָה מִכְּלָלָהּ!
human_translation: This be refuted. Whereas affliction no permitted from its general you say with regard to labor, which permitted from its general
llm_translation: There is room to differentiate: what is the case of something that was not permitted from the outset, you would say in the case of work that was permitted from its outset!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: לֹא יֵאָמֵר עוֹנֶשׁ בְּעִינּוּי, דְּגָמַר מִמְּלָאכָה. מָה מְלָאכָה שֶׁהוּתְּרָה מִכְּלָלָהּ — עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת, עִינּוּי שֶׁלֹּא הוּתַּר מִכְּלָלוֹ — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן. לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר — מוּפְנֶה, לְהַקִּישׁ וְלָדוּן מִמֶּנּוּ גְּזֵירָה שָׁוָה: נֶאֱמַר עוֹנֶשׁ בְּעִינּוּי וְנֶאֱמַר עוֹנֶשׁ בִּמְלָאכָה, מָה מְלָאכָה עָנַשׁ וְהִזְהִיר — אַף עִינּוּי עָנַשׁ וְהִזְהִיר.
human_translation: Rather, not say the punishment for affliction, since one can learn it from labor Just as labor, for which from the general are permitted, is punishable by karet , affliction, which has no permitted from its general not all the more so why is it stated? It is available to compare and learn a verbal analogy: Punishment is stated with regard to affliction, and punishment is stated with regard to labor. Just as for labor punished and warned, so too, for affliction punished and warned.
llm_translation: Rather: it should not be said that punishment is more severe than warning, as it is derived from work. Just as work that is permitted from its general category - punishment is excision, warning that is not permitted from its general category - not to mention. Why is it stated - turned, to compare and deduce from it a similar decree: it is stated punishment in warning and it is stated punishment in work, just as work is punished and warned - so too warning is punished and warned.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא לְמִיפְרַךְ: מָה לִמְלָאכָה — שֶׁכֵּן נוֹהֶגֶת בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וְיָמִים טוֹבִים. תֹּאמַר בְּעִינּוּי — שֶׁאֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בְּשַׁבָּתוֹת וְיָמִים טוֹבִים!
human_translation: can be refuted, Whereas labor is observed on Shabbatot and Festivals, you say about affliction, which is not observed on Shabbatot and Festivals?
llm_translation: There is room to differentiate: What is considered "work" - as is customary on Sabbaths and festivals. One might say in his estimation - that which is not customary on Sabbaths and festivals!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבִינָא: הַאי תַּנָּא, ״עֶצֶם״ ״עֶצֶם״ גָּמַר. מוּפְנֶה, דְּאִי לָא מוּפְנֶה — אִיכָּא לְמִיפְרַךְ כִּדְפָרְכִינַן!
human_translation: Ravina said: this tanna derived same same it is available, as, if it were not available, it could be refuted, as we refuted it
llm_translation: Ravina said: This Mishnah, "etzem" "etzem" he concluded. Mufneh, for if not mufneh — there is room to refute as we explain!

hebrew_text: לָאיֵי, אִפְּנוֹיֵי מוּפְנֶה. חַמְשָׁה קְרָאֵי כְּתִיבִי בִּמְלָאכָה, חַד לְאַזְהָרָה דִימָמָא, וְחַד לְאַזְהָרָה דְלֵילְיָא, וְחַד לְעוֹנֶשׁ דִּימָמָא, וְחַד לְעוֹנֶשׁ דְּלֵילְיָא, וְחַד לְאַפְנוֹיֵי לְמִגְמַר עִינּוּי מִמְּלָאכָה, בֵּין דִּימָמָא בֵּין דְּלֵילְיָא.
human_translation: No, it is certainly available, five verses are written labor One a warning on the day and one for a warning on the night and one for the punishment on the day; and one for the punishment at night; and one to be available to derive affliction from labor, both during the day and night,
llm_translation: To Aiyei, the turning is turned. Five verses written regarding work, one for the prohibition of blood, and one for the prohibition of fat, and one for the punishment of blood, and one for the punishment of fat, and one for turning to complete the prohibition of work, whether by day or by night.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל תָּנָא: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן עִינּוּי, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן עִינּוּי. מָה לְהַלָּן — לֹא עָנַשׁ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן הִזְהִיר, אַף כָּאן — לֹא עָנַשׁ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן הִזְהִיר. רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אָמַר: יָלֵיף ״שַׁבַּת שַׁבָּתוֹן״ מִשַּׁבַּת בְּרֵאשִׁית: מָה לְהַלָּן — לֹא עָנַשׁ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן הִזְהִיר, אַף כָּאן — לֹא עָנַשׁ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן הִזְהִיר.
human_translation: The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught “Affliction” is stated here, and “affliction” is stated later, Just as there, did not punish unless there was warning, so too here, did not punish unless there was warning. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said Derive “Shabbat of solemn rest” from Shabbat of Creation. Just as there, did not punish unless there was warning, so too here, did not punish unless there was warning.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael taught: It is stated here "warning," and it is stated there "warning." Just as there - He only punished if He warned, so too here - He only punished if He warned. Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: "Shabbat Shabbaton" is derived from Shabbat in Genesis: Just as there - He only punished if He warned, so too here - He only punished if He warned.

hebrew_text: רַב פָּפָּא אָמַר:
human_translation: Rav Pappa said:
llm_translation: Rav Papa said:

hebrew_text: הוּא גּוּפֵיהּ שַׁבָּת אִיקְּרִי, דִּכְתִיב: ״תִּשְׁבְּתוּ שַׁבַּתְּכֶם״. בִּשְׁלָמָא רַב פָּפָּא לָא אָמַר כְּרַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב — דִּקְרָא דִּכְתִיב בְּגוּפֵיהּ עֲדִיף. אֶלָּא רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב, מַאי טַעְמָא לָא אָמַר כְּרַב פָּפָּא?
human_translation: itself is called “Shabbat,” as it is written: you shall rest on your Shabbat” Granted, Rav Pappa did not say as Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov a verse that is written about the matter itself is preferable But what is the reason Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov did not state in accordance with the opinion of Rav Pappa?
llm_translation: The body itself Shabbat is called, as it is written: "You shall keep your Shabbat." Now, according to Rav Papa, it is not as Rav Acha bar Yaakov said - for a verse written in its entirety is preferable. Rather, Rav Acha bar Yaakov, what is the reason he did not say like Rav Papa?

hebrew_text: מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: ״וְעִנִּיתֶם אֶת נַפְשׁוֹתֵיכֶם בְּתִשְׁעָה לַחוֹדֶשׁ״. יָכוֹל יַתְחִיל וְיִתְעַנֶּה בְּתִשְׁעָה — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בָּעֶרֶב״. אִי בָּעֶרֶב — יָכוֹל מִשֶּׁתֶּחְשַׁךְ? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בְּתִשְׁעָה״. הָא כֵּיצַד? מַתְחִיל וּמִתְעַנֶּה מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם, מִכָּאן שֶׁמּוֹסִיפִין מֵחוֹל עַל הַקּוֹדֶשׁ.
human_translation: He requires this for that which was taught “And you shall afflict your souls on the ninth day of the month might one should start to afflict oneself on the ninth the verse states “at evening.” If “at evening,” might when darkness falls; the verse states “on the ninth,” How One begins to fast while it is still daytime; from here that one extends from non-sacred to sacred
llm_translation: He asked according to the one who teaches: "And you shall afflict your souls on the ninth of the month." Could one begin and afflict oneself on the ninth? The Torah teaches: "In the evening." If in the evening, could one afflict oneself from when it gets dark? The Torah teaches: "On the ninth." How so? One begins and afflicts oneself from midday, hence we add from the weekday onto the holy day.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין לִי אֶלָּא בִּכְנִיסָתוֹ, בִּיצִיאָתוֹ מִנַּיִן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״מֵעֶרֶב עַד עֶרֶב״. וְאֵין לִי אֶלָּא יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, (יָמִים טוֹבִים) מִנַּיִין — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״תִּשְׁבְּתוּ״. אֵין לִי אֶלָּא (יָמִים טוֹבִים, שַׁבָּתוֹת) מִנַּיִן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שַׁבַּתְּכֶם״. הָא כֵּיצַד? כׇּל מָקוֹם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר שְׁבוּת, (מִכָּאן שֶׁ)מוֹסִיפִין מֵחוֹל עַל הַקּוֹדֶשׁ.
human_translation: I have only at the beginning From where at the conclusion of The verse states: “From evening until evening” And I only Yom Kippur; from where Festivals? The verse states: “You shall rest” I have only Festivals; from where Shabbatot ? The verse states: “Your Shabbat” How so? Every place the term: Rest [ shevut ] is stated, from here that one appends from non-sacred to sacred.
llm_translation: "And I have only at its entrance, at its exit, from where? — the Talmud teaches to say: 'from evening to evening.' And I have only Yom Kippur, (festivals) from where? — the Talmud teaches to say: 'you shall rest.' And I have only (festivals, Sabbaths) from where? — the Talmud teaches to say: 'your Sabbaths.' How so? Any place where it is stated 'rest,' (from here) we add from the weekday onto the holy."

hebrew_text: וְתַנָּא דְּ״עֶצֶם״ ״עֶצֶם״, הַאי ״בְּתִשְׁעָה לַחוֹדֶשׁ״ מַאי עָבֵיד לֵיהּ? מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתָנֵי חִיָּיא בַּר רַב מִדִּיפְתִּי. דְּתָנֵי חִיָּיא בַּר רַב מִדִּיפְתִּי: ״וְעִנִּיתֶם אֶת נַפְשׁוֹתֵיכֶם בְּתִשְׁעָה״, וְכִי בְּתִשְׁעָה מִתְעַנִּין? וַהֲלֹא בֶּעָשׂוֹר מִתְעַנִּין! אֶלָּא לוֹמַר לְךָ: כָּל הָאוֹכֵל וְשׁוֹתֶה בִּתְשִׁיעִי, מַעֲלֶה עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב כְּאִילּוּ הִתְעַנָּה תְּשִׁיעִי וַעֲשִׂירִי.
human_translation: And the tanna same same what does he do with “On the ninth day of the month”? He requires it, in accordance with which Ḥiyya bar Rav of Difti taught. As Ḥiyya bar Rav of Difti taught: “And you shall afflict your souls on the ninth But does one afflict oneself on the ninth Doesn’t one afflict oneself on the tenth Rather, to tell you: Anyone who eats and drinks on the ninth the verse ascribes him as though he fasted on ninth and the tenth.
llm_translation: And it was taught in a Baraita: "With regard to 'etzem' ('bone'), what does one do on the 'ninth of the month'? He should fast on it, as it was taught by Hiyya bar Rav from Difti. For Hiyya bar Rav from Difti taught: 'And you shall afflict your souls on the ninth.' But do they fast on the ninth? Is it not on the tenth that they fast? Rather, this is to tell you: Anyone who eats and drinks on the ninth, the Scripture accounts it to him as if he had fasted on the ninth and the tenth."

hebrew_text: אָכַל אוֹכָלִין שֶׁאֵין רְאוּיִן לַאֲכִילָה. אָמַר רָבָא: כַּס פִּלְפְּלֵי בְּיוֹמָא דְכִפּוּרֵי — פָּטוּר. כַּס זַנְגְּבִילָא בְּיוֹמָא דְכִפּוּרֵי — פָּטוּר.
human_translation: ate food that is fit for eating, Rava said: one chews pepper on Yom Kippur, he is exempt, one chews ginger [ zangvila ] on Yom Kippur, he is exempt.
llm_translation: Eating foods that are not fit for consumption. Rava said: If one ate pepper on Yom Kippur - exempt. If one ate ginger on Yom Kippur - exempt.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי, הָיָה רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: מִמַּשְׁמַע שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַעֲרַלְתֶּם עׇרְלָתוֹ אֶת פִּרְיוֹ״, אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁעֵץ מַאֲכָל הוּא! אֶלָּא מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״עֵץ מַאֲכָל״? עֵץ שֶׁטַּעַם עֵצוֹ וּפִרְיוֹ שָׁוֶה, הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר זֶה פִּלְפְּלִין, לְלַמֶּדְךָ שֶׁהַפִּלְפְּלִין חַיָּיבִין בְּעׇרְלָה. וְאֵין אֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל חֲסֵרָה כְּלוּם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״לֹא תֶחְסַר כֹּל בָּהּ״!
human_translation: raises an objection Rabbi Meir would say From the implication of what is stated: “Then you shall count the fruit of it as forbidden,” do I not know that “trees for food,” Rather, what the verse states “trees for food”? a tree whose wood and fruit taste the same, must say this pepper to teach you that pepper is subject to of orla . And Eretz Yisrael lacks nothing, as it is stated “You will not lack anything in it”
llm_translation: The Tanna raises an objection: Rabbi Meir used to say, is it really derived from what is stated: "And you shall uncircumcise the foreskin of its fruit," that it is a fruit-bearing tree? Rather, what is the purpose of the verse stating "fruit-bearing tree"? A tree whose taste and fruit are similar, you should say this refers to peppers, to teach you that peppers are subject to the laws of orlah. And the Land of Israel lacks nothing, as it is stated: "Nothing is lacking in it!"

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — בְּרַטִּיבְתָּא, וְהָא — בְּיַבִּישְׁתָּא.
human_translation: This not difficult. This to moist; and that dry
llm_translation: Not difficult: this - in the wet, and this - in the dry.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְמָרִימָר: וְהָאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן, הַאי הִימְלְתָא דְּאָתֵי מִבֵּי הִנְדּוּאֵי — שַׁרְיָא, וּמְבָרְכִינַן עֲלֵיהּ: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּרַטִּיבְתָּא, וְהָא בְּיַבִּישְׁתָּא.
human_translation: Ravina said to Mareimar: But didn’t Rav Naḥman say it is permitted this cooked ginger [ himalta ] that comes from India, And we recite the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground, over it. This not difficult: This to wet and that to dry
llm_translation: Ravina said to Marimar: And didn't Rav Nachman say, this garment that comes from the house of launderers - it is permitted, and we recite over it: "Who creates the fruit of the earth." There is no difficulty: this is in the wet state, and this is in the dry state.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אָכַל עֲלֵי קָנִים — פָּטוּר. לוּלְבֵי גְפָנִים — חַיָּיב. אֵלּוּ הֵן לוּלְבֵי גְפָנִים? אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק מִגְדְּלָאָה: כׇּל שֶׁלִּבְלְבוּ מֵרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְעַד יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים. וְרַב כָּהֲנָא אָמַר: כׇּל שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם. תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יִצְחָק מִגְדְּלָאָה: אָכַל עֲלֵי קָנִים — פָּטוּר, וְלוּלְבֵי גְפָנִים — חַיָּיב. אֵלּוּ הֵן לוּלְבֵי גְפָנִים — כׇּל שֶׁלִּבְלְבוּ מֵרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וְעַד יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים.
human_translation: The Sages taught one ate leaves of reeds he is exempt, grapevine shoots he is liable. What are these grapevine shoots? Rabbi Yitzḥak from Migdal said: All that sprouted between Rosh HaShana and Yom Kippur And Rav Kahana said: thirty days It was taught in accordance with Rabbi Yitzḥak from Migdal: one ate leaves of reeds he is exempt, but grapevine shoots he is liable. What are these grapevine shoots? all those that sprouted between Rosh HaShana and Yom Kippur.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One who eats from reeds - exempt. One who eats from grapevines - liable. What are grapevines? Rabbi Yitzchak of Magdala said: Any that have leaves from the beginning of the year until Yom Kippur. And Rav Kahana said: Any within thirty days. It was taught in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yitzchak of Magdala: One who eats from reeds - exempt, and one who eats from grapevines - liable. What are grapevines? Any that have leaves from the beginning of the year until Yom Kippur.

hebrew_text: שָׁתָה צִיר אוֹ מוּרְיָיס — פָּטוּר. הָא חוֹמֶץ — חַיָּיב. מַתְנִיתִין מַנִּי? רַבִּי הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: חוֹמֶץ מֵשִׁיב אֶת הַנֶּפֶשׁ.
human_translation: drank fish brine or liquid he is exempt. if one drank vinegar, he is liable. Who is the mishna? It is Rabbi as it was taught Rabbi says: Vinegar revives the spirit
llm_translation: He who drinks vinegar or moruys - exempt. But if it is vinegar - liable. Where is this Mishnah from? It is from Rabbi Hiya. As it was taught: Rabbi says: Vinegar restores the soul.

hebrew_text: דָּרֵשׁ רַב גִּידֵּל בַּר מְנַשֶּׁה מִבֵּירֵי דְנַרֶשׁ: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי. לְשָׁנָה נָפְקִי כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא מָזְגוּ וְשָׁתוּ חַלָּא. שְׁמַע רַב גִּידֵּל וְאִיקְּפַד. אֲמַר: אֵימַר דַּאֲמַרִי אֲנָא — דִּיעֲבַד, לְכַתְּחִלָּה מִי אֲמַרִי? אֵימַר דַּאֲמַרִי אֲנָא — פּוּרְתָּא, טוּבָא מִי אֲמַרִי? אֵימַר דַּאֲמַרִי אֲנָא — חַי, מָזוּג מִי אֲמַרִי?
human_translation: Rav Giddel bar Menashe from Birei DeNeresh taught halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi The year everyone went out and mixed and drank vinegar Rav Giddel heard and became angry He said: Say that I said only after the fact; did I say ab initio ? Say that I said a little, did I say a lot? Say that I said pure but did I say diluted
llm_translation: Rav Gidel son of Menasheh from the town of Naresheh expounded: The halakha does not follow Rabbi. In that year, everyone in the world poured and drank milk. Rav Gidel heard and was distressed. He said: If I had said something, would they have listened to me at the outset? If I had said something, would they have said it was good? If I had said something, would they have said it was living, who would have said it was mixed?

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַתִּינוֹקוֹת אֵין מְעַנִּין אוֹתָן בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, אֲבָל מְחַנְּכִין אוֹתָן לִפְנֵי שָׁנָה וְלִפְנֵי שְׁנָתַיִים, בִּשְׁבִיל שֶׁיִּהְיוּ רְגִילִין בְּמִצְוֹת.
human_translation: the children, one does not afflict them on Yom Kippur; however, one trains them one year before or two years before so that they will be accustomed to mitzvot.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "Infants are not fasted on Yom Kippur, but they are trained before one year and before two years, so that they become accustomed to the commandments."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הַשְׁתָּא בִּפְנֵי שְׁתַּיִם מְחַנְּכִין לְהוּ — בִּפְנֵי שָׁנָה מִבַּעְיָא? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא, לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — בְּחוֹלֶה, הָא — בְּבָרִיא.
human_translation: Since two before necessary to say that one trains them one year before? Rav Ḥisda said: not difficult. This to a feeble that to a healthy
llm_translation: Gemara: "When it comes to circumcision, two are needed to perform it - is it needed during the day or at night? Rav Ḥisda said, it is not difficult: here - for a sick person, here - for a healthy person."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: בֶּן שְׁמוֹנֶה וּבֶן תֵּשַׁע — מְחַנְּכִין אוֹתוֹ לְשָׁעוֹת. בֶּן עֶשֶׂר וּבֶן אַחַת עֶשְׂרֵה — מַשְׁלִימִין מִדְּרַבָּנַן, בֶּן שְׁתֵּים עֶשְׂרֵה — מַשְׁלִימִין מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא בְּתִינוֹקֶת. וְרַב נַחְמָן אָמַר: בֶּן תֵּשַׁע בֶּן עֶשֶׂר — מְחַנְּכִין אוֹתָן לְשָׁעוֹת, בֶּן אַחַת עֶשְׂרֵה בֶּן שְׁתֵּים עֶשְׂרֵה — מַשְׁלִימִין מִדְּרַבָּנַן, בֶּן שְׁלֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה — מַשְׁלִימִין מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא בְּתִינוֹק. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: הַשְׁלָמָה דְּרַבָּנַן לֵיכָּא. בֶּן עֶשֶׂר בֶּן אַחַת עֶשְׂרֵה — מְחַנְּכִין אוֹתוֹ לְשָׁעוֹת, בֶּן שְׁתֵּים עֶשְׂרֵה — מַשְׁלִימִין מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא.
human_translation: Rav Huna said: One trains of eight and nine for hours; ten and eleven they complete by rabbinic at twelve they complete by Torah to girls And Rav Naḥman said: At nine ten one trains them for hours; at eleven and twelve they complete by rabbinic at thirteen they complete by Torah to boys. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: There is no completing by rabbinic at ten and eleven one trains them for hours; and at twelve complete by Torah
llm_translation: Rav Huna said: A child of eight or nine - we educate him for hours. A child of ten or eleven - we add from the Rabbinic teachings. A child of twelve - we add from the Torah in his childhood. And Rav Nachman said: A child of nine or ten - we educate them for hours, a child of eleven or twelve - we add from the Rabbinic teachings, a child of thirteen - we add from the Torah in his childhood. And Rabbi Yochanan said: The completion of the Rabbinic teachings is not necessary. A child of ten or eleven - we educate him for hours, a child of twelve - we add from the Torah.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: הַתִּינוֹקוֹת אֵין מְעַנִּין אוֹתָן בַּיּוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, אֲבָל מְחַנְּכִין אוֹתָן לִפְנֵי שָׁנָה וְלִפְנֵי שְׁתַּיִם. בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַב הוּנָא וְרַב נַחְמָן — לִפְנֵי שָׁנָה וְלִפְנֵי שְׁתַּיִם. לִפְנֵי שָׁנָה — לְדִבְרֵיהֶן, וְלִפְנֵי שְׁתַּיִם — לְדִבְרֵיהֶן.
human_translation: We learned the children, one does not afflict them on Yom Kippur; however, one trains them one year before or two before Granted, Rav Huna and Rav Naḥman, one year before or two before year before by rabbinic and two before by rabbinic
llm_translation: We learned: Infants are not involved on Yom Kippur, but they are initiated before one year and before two years. According to Rav Huna and Rav Nahman - before one year and before two years. Before one year - according to their words, and before two years - according to their words.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, קַשְׁיָא? אָמַר לָךְ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאי שָׁנָה אוֹ שְׁתַּיִם — סָמוּךְ לְפִירְקָן.
human_translation: But to Rabbi Yoḥanan, difficult. Rabbi Yoḥanan said to you: What one year or two preceding their maturity.
llm_translation: Rather, to Rabbi Yochanan, is it difficult? Rabbi Yochanan said to you: What is the difference of one or two? Close to their explanation.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּתָנֵי רַבָּה בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל: תִּינוֹקוֹת אֵין מְעַנִּין אוֹתָן בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, אֲבָל מְחַנְּכִין אוֹתָן שָׁנָה אוֹ שְׁתַּיִם סָמוּךְ לְפִירְקָן. בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן — נִיחָא, אֶלָּא לְרַב הוּנָא וּלְרַב נַחְמָן — קַשְׁיָא! אָמְרִי לָךְ רַבָּנַן: מַאי חִינּוּךְ נָמֵי דְּקָתָנֵי — הַשְׁלָמָה.
human_translation: Come hear that Rabba bar Shmuel taught children, one does not afflict them on Yom Kippur; however, one trains them one year or two preceding their maturity. Granted, to Rabbi Yoḥanan, this works out well; but to Rav Huna and Rav Naḥman, difficult. The Rabbis say to you: What is training that is also taught a complete
llm_translation: Come and hear, as Rabba bar Shmuel teaches: Infants are not engaged on the Day of Atonement, but they are educated a year or two before their maturity. According to Rabbi Yochanan, this is well and good, but according to Rav Huna and Rav Nachman, it is difficult! The Rabbis say to you: What is the meaning of "education" as it is taught? Completion.

hebrew_text: וּמִי קָרֵי לְחִינּוּךְ הַשְׁלָמָה, וְהָא תַּנְיָא: אֵי זֶה חִינּוּךְ? הָיָה רָגִיל לֶאֱכוֹל בִּשְׁתֵּי שָׁעוֹת — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ לְשָׁלֹשׁ. בְּשָׁלֹשׁ — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ בְּאַרְבַּע. אָמַר רָבָא בַּר עוּלָּא: תְּרֵי חִנּוּכֵי הָווּ.
human_translation: And is training called completion? Wasn’t taught What is training? If was accustomed to eat at the second one feeds him at the third at the third one feeds him at the fourth Rava bar Ulla said: these are two training.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And who is called for the training of peace, and this is taught: What is this training? If he was accustomed to eat in two hours - they feed him in three. In three - they feed him in four. Rava bar Ulla said: There were two trainings.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ עוּבָּרָה שֶׁהֵרִיחָה — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתָהּ עַד שֶׁתָּשִׁיב נַפְשָׁהּ. חוֹלֶה — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי בְּקִיאִין, וְאִם אֵין שָׁם בְּקִיאִין — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי עַצְמוֹ עַד שֶׁיֹּאמַר דַּי.
human_translation: a pregnant woman who smelled one feeds her until she recovers, ill one feeds him according to experts And if there are no experts there, one feeds him according to his own until he says enough
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A pregnant woman who smells food — we feed her until she feels satisfied. If one is ill — we feed him according to the advice of experts, and if there are no experts present — we feed him according to his own judgment until he says "enough."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: עוּבָּרָה שֶׁהֵרִיחָה בְּשַׂר קוֹדֶשׁ אוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר — תּוֹחֲבִין לָהּ כּוּשׁ בְּרוֹטֶב, וּמַנִּיחִין לָהּ עַל פִּיהָ, אִם נִתְיַישְּׁבָה דַּעְתָּהּ — מוּטָב, וְאִם לָאו — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתָהּ רוֹטֶב עַצְמוֹ, וְאִם נִתְיַישְּׁבָה דַּעְתָּהּ — מוּטָב, וְאִם לָאו — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתָהּ שׁוּמָּן עַצְמוֹ. שֶׁאֵין לְךָ דָּבָר שֶׁעוֹמֵד בִּפְנֵי פִּקּוּחַ נֶפֶשׁ, חוּץ מֵעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה וְגִילּוּי עֲרָיוֹת וּשְׁפִיכוּת דָּמִים.
human_translation: The Sages taught a pregnant woman who smelled consecrated meat or pig meat one inserts a thin reed into the juice and places it on her mouth. If her mind become settled it is well. And if not, one feeds her the gravy itself If her mind becomes settled it is well. And if not, one feeds her the fat itself, as there is no that stands in the way of saving a life except for idol worship, and forbidden sexual relationships, and bloodshed.
llm_translation: The sages taught: If a pregnant woman smelled holy meat or pig meat — they smear on her Ethiopian myrrh, and they place it on her mouth. If her mind settled — it is better, and if not — they feed her the myrrh itself, and if her mind settled — it is better, and if not — they feed her the fat itself. For there is nothing that stands in the way of saving a life, except for idolatry, sexual immorality, and shedding blood.

hebrew_text: עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה מְנָלַן — דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אִם נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל נַפְשְׁךָ״, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל מְאֹדֶךָ״? וְאִם נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל מְאֹדֶךָ״, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל נַפְשְׁךָ״?
human_translation: idol worship from where we As it was taught Rabbi Eliezer says: If it is stated: and with all your soul” why is it stated “And with all your might” And if it is stated: “With all your might,” why is it stated: “With all your soul”?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Avodah Zarah menalan - d'tanya, Rabbi Eliezer omer: Im ne'emar "b'chol nafshecha," lamah ne'emar "b'chol me'odecha"? Ve'im ne'emar "b'chol me'odecha," lamah ne'emar "b'chol nafshecha"? English translation: Idolatry from where is it derived? - For it was taught, Rabbi Eliezer says: If it is stated "with all your soul," why is it also stated "with all your might"? And if it is stated "with all your might," why is it also stated "with all your soul"?

hebrew_text: אִם יֵשׁ לְךָ אָדָם שֶׁגּוּפוֹ חָבִיב עָלָיו מִמָּמוֹנוֹ — לְכָךְ נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכׇל נַפְשְׁךָ״, וְאִם יֵשׁ לָךְ אָדָם שֶׁמָּמוֹנוֹ חָבִיב עָלָיו מִגּוּפוֹ — לְכָךְ נֶאֱמַר ״וּבְכׇל מְאֹדֶךָ״.
human_translation: if there is a person whose body is more beloved to him than his property, therefore it is stated: “With all your soul.” And if there is a person whose property is more beloved to him than his body, therefore it is stated: “With all your might.”
llm_translation: If you have a person whose body is dearer to him than his money - therefore it is said, "with all your soul." And if you have a person whose money is dearer to him than his body - therefore it is said, "and with all your might."

hebrew_text: גִּילּוּי עֲרָיוֹת וּשְׁפִיכַת דָּמִים מְנָא לַן — דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: ״כִּי כַּאֲשֶׁר יָקוּם אִישׁ עַל רֵעֵהוּ וּרְצָחוֹ נֶפֶשׁ כֵּן הַדָּבָר הַזֶּה״. וְכִי מָה עִנְיָן לָמַדְנוּ מֵרוֹצֵחַ לְנַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה?
human_translation: forbidden sexual relations or shed blood from where we As it was taught Rabbi says: “For as when a man rises against his fellow and slays him, even so is this matter” What idea did we learn about a betrothed woman from a murderer?
llm_translation: The revelation of forbidden relationships and the shedding of blood - from where do we derive this? As it was taught: Rabbi says, "For just as a man rises against his neighbor and murders him, so is this matter." And what relevance have we learned from a murderer to a betrothed maiden?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: הֲרֵי זֶה בָּא לְלַמֵּד, וְנִמְצָא לָמֵד: מָה נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה נִיתָּן לְהַצִּילָהּ בְּנַפְשׁוֹ — אַף רוֹצֵחַ (כּוּ׳). מָה רוֹצֵחַ יֵהָרֵג וְאַל יַעֲבוֹר — אַף נַעֲרָה הַמְאוֹרָסָה יֵהָרֵג וְאַל יַעֲבוֹר.
human_translation: Rather, this come to teach is found to subject of teaching. Just as the betrothed woman, given to save her at life of so too, murderer Just as murderer let him be killed, and let him not transgress, so too, a betrothed young woman. let him be killed, and let him not transgress,
llm_translation: Rather, this comes to teach, and it is found taught: Just as a betrothed maiden may be saved at the cost of the life of the pursuer — so too, a murderer. Just as a murderer should be killed and not transgress — so too, a betrothed maiden should be killed and not transgress.

hebrew_text: וְרוֹצֵחַ גּוּפֵיהּ מְנָא לַן? סְבָרָא הִיא: דְּהָהוּא דַּאֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ (דְּרָבָא), אֲמַר לֵיהּ, אֲמַר לִי מָרֵי דּוּרַאי: קִטְלֵיהּ לִפְלָנְיָא, וְאִי לָא — קָטֵילְנָא לָךְ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נִקְטְלָךְ וְלָא תִּקְטוֹל. מַאי חָזֵית דִּדְמָא דִּידָךְ סוּמָּק טְפֵי? דִּילְמָא דְּמָא דְּהָהוּא גַּבְרָא סוּמָּק טְפֵי!
human_translation: And murderer himself, from where we It is reason, A certain came before Rava. He said to The master of the village said to me: Kill so-and-so, and if not I will kill you. said to him: Let yourself be killed, and you should not kill. What did you see that your blood is redder Perhaps the blood of that man is redder,
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: "And how do we establish the guilt of the murderer? It is a logical deduction: When that person (came) before (Rava), he said to him, 'My master, the man of such and such a generation told me: Kill so-and-so, and if not — I will kill you.' He said to him: 'Let yourself be killed and do not kill.' What do you see that your blood is redder? Perhaps the blood of that man is redder!"

hebrew_text: הָהִיא עוּבָּרָה דְּאָרַחָא, אֲתוֹ לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי, אֲמַר לְהוּ: זִילוּ לְחוּשׁוּ לַהּ דְּיוֹמָא דְכִיפּוּרֵי הוּא. לְחוּשׁוּ לָהּ וְאִילְּחִישָׁא. קָרֵי עֲלֵיהּ: ״בְּטֶרֶם אֶצָּרְךָ בַבֶּטֶן יְדַעְתִּיךָ וְגוֹ׳״. נְפַק מִינַּהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן.
human_translation: A certain pregnant woman smelled came before Rabbi He said to those Go and whisper to her that today is Yom Kippur. They whispered to her, and this whispering helped; read about “Before I formed you in the belly I knew you, came out of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
llm_translation: That pregnant woman who was walking on the road, came before Rabbi, he said to them: Go be cautious for her, for it is the day of atonements. Be cautious for her and hurry. He read upon her: "Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, and so forth." Rabbi Yochanan was relieved of her.

hebrew_text: הָהִיא עוּבָּרָה דְּאָרַחָא, אֲתוֹ לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא. אֲמַר לְהוּ: לְחוּשׁוּ לָהּ, וְלָא אִילְּחִישָׁא. קָרֵי עֲלֵיהּ:
human_translation: A certain pregnant woman smelled came before Rabbi Ḥanina He said to them: Whisper to her she did not accept the whisper read about
llm_translation: That pregnant woman who was walking on the road, they brought her before Rabbi Chanina. He said to them: "Be concerned for her, and do not be unconcerned." He read upon her:

hebrew_text: ״זוֹרוּ רְשָׁעִים מֵרָחֶם״. נְפַק מִינַּהּ שַׁבְּתַאי אָצַר פֵּירֵי.
human_translation: “The wicked are estranged from the womb” Shabbetai the hoarder of fruits came out of her.
llm_translation: "Zoru reshaim merachem." Nafka minah Shabbetai atzar peirei.

hebrew_text: חוֹלֶה מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי בְּקִיאִין. אָמַר רַבִּי יַנַּאי: חוֹלֶה אוֹמֵר צָרִיךְ, וְרוֹפֵא אוֹמֵר אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ — שׁוֹמְעִין לַחוֹלֶה. מַאי טַעְמָא — ״לֵב יוֹדֵעַ מׇרַּת נַפְשׁוֹ״. פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: רוֹפֵא קִים לֵיהּ טְפֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: ill one feeds him according to experts. Rabbi Yannai said: an ill person says needs and a doctor says he does not need one listens to the ill person. What is the reason “The heart knows the bitterness of its soul” obvious lest you say the doctor is more certain teaches us
llm_translation: The sick person, we feed him according to the experts. Rabbi Yannai said: The sick person says he needs it, and the doctor says he doesn't need it - we listen to the sick person. What is the reason? "The heart knows the bitterness of one's soul." It is obvious! Lest you say: the doctor is more knowledgeable, we have heard.

hebrew_text: רוֹפֵא אוֹמֵר צָרִיךְ, וְחוֹלֶה אוֹמֵר אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ — שׁוֹמְעִין לָרוֹפֵא. מַאי טַעְמָא — תּוּנְבָּא הוּא דְּנָקֵיט לֵיהּ.
human_translation: a doctor says needs but the ill person says he does not need one listens to the doctor. What is the reason confusion [ tunba ] has taken hold
llm_translation: The healer says it is necessary, and the sick person says it is not necessary - we listen to the healer. What is the reason? It is a matter of a splinter that he takes out.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: חוֹלֶה — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי בְּקִיאִין. עַל פִּי בְּקִיאִין — אִין, עַל פִּי עַצְמוֹ — לָא! עַל פִּי בְּקִיאִין — אִין, עַל פִּי בָּקִי אֶחָד — לָא!
human_translation: We learned ill, one feeds him according to experts. according to experts, yes, his own no, according to experts, yes, according to one expert, no,
llm_translation: We learned in the Mishnah: Regarding a sick person — we feed him according to the expert's opinion. According to the expert's opinion — yes, according to his own opinion — no! According to the expert's opinion — yes, according to the opinion of one expert — no!

hebrew_text: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן, דְּאָמַר לָא צְרִיכְנָא. וְלִיסְפּוֹ לֵיהּ עַל פִּי בָּקִי! לָא צְרִיכָא, דְּאִיכָּא אַחֲרִינָא בַּהֲדֵיהּ דְּאָמַר לָא צְרִיךְ — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי בְּקִיאִין.
human_translation: With what are we dealing here? says I do not need But let them feed him according to one expert, No, necessary where there is another, with him who says does not need one feeds according to experts
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with what? That he said it is not necessary. And let him add to it according to the mouth of a knowledgeable person! It is not necessary, for there is another opinion alongside his that said it is not necessary — we feed him according to knowledgeable individuals.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא, סְפֵק נְפָשׁוֹת הוּא, וּסְפֵק נְפָשׁוֹת לְהָקֵל! לָא צְרִיכָא, דְּאִיכָּא תְּרֵי אַחֲרִינֵי בַּהֲדֵיהּ דְּאָמְרִי לָא צְרִיךְ. וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּאָמַר רַב סָפְרָא: תְּרֵי כִּמְאָה וּמְאָה כִּתְרֵי, הָנֵי מִילֵּי לְעִנְיַן עֵדוּת, אֲבָל לְעִנְיַן אוּמְדָּנָא — בָּתַר דֵּעוֹת אָזְלִינַן.
human_translation: obvious, it is uncertainty life-threatening uncertainty life-threatening is lenient. No, necessary where there are two other with say he does not need And although Rav Safra said two are like one hundred and one hundred are like two that rule applies to the matter of testimony; however, matter of assessing we follow opinions.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: It is obvious, it is a doubt of life, and in a doubt of life, we are lenient! It is not necessary, for there are two others with it that say it is not necessary. And even though Rav Safra said: Two like one hundred and one hundred like two, those words are for matters of testimony, but for matters of estimation - we follow the majority opinion.

hebrew_text: וְהָנֵי מִילֵּי לְעִנְיַן אוּמְדָּנָא דְמָמוֹנָא, אֲבָל הָכָא סְפֵק נְפָשׁוֹת הוּא.
human_translation: However, this applies to assessing monetary but here uncertainty life-threatening
llm_translation: And these are the matters regarding the evaluation of money, but here it is a case of doubt regarding lives.

hebrew_text: וְהָא מִדְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: וְאִם אֵין שָׁם בְּקִיאִין מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי עַצְמוֹ, מִכְּלָל דְּרֵישָׁא דְּאָמַר צָרִיךְ! חַסּוֹרֵי מִיחַסְּרָא וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — דְּאָמַר לֹא צָרִיךְ אֲנִי, אֲבָל אָמַר צָרִיךְ אֲנִי, אֵין שָׁם בְּקִיאִין תְּרֵי אֶלָּא חַד דְּאָמַר לֹא צָרִיךְ — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי עַצְמוֹ.
human_translation: But from that it is taught the latter clause if there are no experts present one feeds him according to his own opinion, by inference, the first clause the ill person said he needs is incomplete and is teaching the following: In what is this statement said? said: I do not need But he said: I do need instead of two experts there is one who says he does not need one feeds him according to his own opinion.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And this is learned in the latter clause: And if there are not knowledgeable individuals there, one may feed him according to his own discretion, which implies the first clause, which stated that he must say, "I do not need," but if he said, "I need," and there are not two knowledgeable individuals, but only one, if he said, "I do not need," he may feed himself.

hebrew_text: מָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: כֹּל הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר צָרִיךְ אֲנִי, אֲפִילּוּ אִיכָּא מְאָה דְּאָמְרִי לֹא צָרִיךְ לְדִידֵיהּ שָׁמְעִינַן — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֵב יוֹדֵעַ מׇרַּת נַפְשׁוֹ״.
human_translation: Mar bar Rav Ashi said: Any where says: I need even if there are one hundred who say he does not need we listen to his own as it is stated: “The heart knows the bitterness of its soul”
llm_translation: Mar bar Rav Ashi said: Wherever it says "I need," even if there are one hundred who say "I do not need," we listen to him - as it is stated: "A heart knows the bitterness of its soul."

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: אִם אֵין שָׁם בְּקִיאִין — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי עַצְמוֹ. טַעְמָא דְּלֵיכָּא בְּקִיאִין, הָא אִיכָּא בְּקִיאִין לָא! הָכִי קָאָמַר: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — דְּאָמַר ״לֹא צָרִיךְ אֲנִי״, אֲבָל אָמַר ״צָרִיךְ אֲנִי״, אֵין שָׁם בְּקִיאִין כְּלָל — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ עַל פִּי עַצְמוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֵב יוֹדֵעַ מׇרַּת נַפְשׁוֹ״.
human_translation: We learned If there are no experts present, one feeds him according to his own opinion. the reason is there are no experts there were experts no, This is is saying: In what is this statement said? when said: I do not need However, he said: I do need there were no experts there at all; we feed him based on his opinion, as it is stated: “The heart knows the bitterness of its soul”
llm_translation: We learned in the Mishnah: If there are no experts present - one feeds himself. The reason for this is that if there are no experts present, then there are no experts at all! This is what it means to say: In a case where one says, "I do not need it," but if one says, "I need it," and there are no experts present at all - one feeds himself, as it is stated: "A heart knows the bitterness of its soul."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁאֲחָזוֹ בּוּלְמוֹס — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ אֲפִילּוּ דְּבָרִים טְמֵאִים, עַד שֶׁיֵּאוֹרוּ עֵינָיו. מִי שֶׁנְּשָׁכוֹ כֶּלֶב שׁוֹטֶה — אֵין מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ מֵחֲצַר כָּבֵד שֶׁלּוֹ. וְרַבִּי מַתְיָא בֶּן חָרָשׁ מַתִּיר.
human_translation: one who is seized bulmos , one feed him even impure foods until his eyes recover, one whom a mad dog bit, one not feed him from the lobe of liver. And Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash permits
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who is bitten by a mad dog – we do not feed him from his heavy courtyard until his eyes are illuminated. Rabbi Matya ben Charash permits it.

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד אָמַר רַבִּי מַתְיָא בֶּן חָרָשׁ: הַחוֹשֵׁשׁ בִּגְרוֹנוֹ — מְטִילִין לוֹ סַם בְּתוֹךְ פִּיו בְּשַׁבָּת, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא סְפֵק נְפָשׁוֹת, וְכׇל סְפֵק נְפָשׁוֹת דּוֹחֶה אֶת הַשַּׁבָּת.
human_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash said: one who suffers pain in his throat, one place medicine inside his mouth on Shabbat, because uncertainty life-threatening And uncertainty life-threatening overrides Shabbat.
llm_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Matya ben Charash said: One who is choking - we place medicine in his mouth on Shabbat, because it is a doubt regarding his life, and any doubt regarding life overrides the Sabbath.

hebrew_text: מִי שֶׁנָּפְלָה עָלָיו מַפּוֹלֶת, סָפֵק הוּא שָׁם סָפֵק אֵינוֹ שָׁם, סָפֵק חַי סָפֵק מֵת, סָפֵק גּוֹי סָפֵק יִשְׂרָאֵל, מְפַקְּחִין עָלָיו אֶת הַגַּל. מְצָאוּהוּ חַי — מְפַקְּחִין, וְאִם מֵת — יְנִיחוּהוּ.
human_translation: one upon whom a rockslide fell, uncertainty he is there he is not there; and uncertainty alive dead; and uncertainty a gentile a Jew, one clears the pile atop him. they found him alive they clear And if dead, they leave him,
llm_translation: One who is struck by a falling building, it is uncertain whether he is there or not, uncertain whether he is alive or dead, uncertain whether he is a gentile or an Israelite, they remove the rubble from him. If they find him alive, they remove it, and if he is dead, they leave him.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מִנַּיִין הָיוּ יוֹדְעִין שֶׁהֵאִירוּ עֵינָיו — מִשֶּׁיַּבְחִין בֵּין טוֹב לָרַע. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: וּבְטַעְמָא.
human_translation: The Sages taught: From where would they know that his eyes had recovered from when he can discern between good and bad Abaye said: with tasting.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: From where do we know that they illuminated his eyes - when they distinguished between good and evil. Abaye said: And with reason.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מִי שֶׁאֲחָזוֹ בּוּלְמוֹס — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ הַקַּל הַקַּל, טֶבֶל וּנְבֵילָה — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ נְבֵילָה. טֶבֶל וּשְׁבִיעִית — שְׁבִיעִית.
human_translation: The Sages taught: one who is seized bulmos one feeds him the least untithed produce an unslaughtered animal carcass [ neveila ] one feeds him neveila , untithed produce and Sabbatical Year, Sabbatical Year.
llm_translation: The sages taught: One who holds a bulmos - feeds him the lightest of light, tevel and neveilah - feeds him neveilah. Tevel and shvi'it - shvi'it.

hebrew_text: טֶבֶל וּתְרוּמָה — תַּנָּאֵי הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ טֶבֶל וְאֵין מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ תְּרוּמָה. בֶּן תֵּימָא אוֹמֵר: תְּרוּמָה וְלֹא טֶבֶל. אָמַר רַבָּה: הֵיכָא דְּאֶפְשָׁר בְּחוּלִּין, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דִּמְתַקְּנִינַן לֵיהּ וּמַסְפִּינַן לֵיהּ.
human_translation: untithed produce and teruma , is tanna’im as it was taught One feeds him untithed produce and does not feed him teruma . Ben Teima says: teruma and not untithed produce. Rabba said: Where it is possible him non-sacred food everyone agrees that one should make fit and feed to him,
llm_translation: Tevul and terumah — it is a teaching. As it was taught: one may feed him tevul but one may not feed him terumah. Ben Teima says: terumah but not tevul. Rabbah said: in a case where it is possible with common food, since everyone agrees that we can fix it and make it acceptable.

hebrew_text: כִּי פְּלִיגִי בִּדְלָא אֶפְשָׁר בְּחוּלִּין. מָר סָבַר טֶבֶל חָמוּר, וּמַר סָבַר תְּרוּמָה חֲמוּרָה. מָר סָבַר טֶבֶל חָמוּר — אֲבָל תְּרוּמָה חַזְיָא לְכֹהֵן. וּמַר סָבַר תְּרוּמָה חֲמוּרָה, אֲבָל טֶבֶל אֶפְשָׁר לְתַקּוֹנֵיהּ.
human_translation: Where they disagree, where it is impossible non-sacred food One Sage holds untithed produce is more severe; and one Sage holds teruma is more severe. Sage holds that untithed produce is severe but teruma is fit for a priest, And one Sage holds that teruma is severe while untithed produce can be made fit
llm_translation: When they argued about something that cannot be resolved with ordinary cases, Mar said Tevel is stringent, and Mar said Terumah is stringent. Mar said Tevel is stringent - but Terumah is fit for a priest. And Mar said Terumah is stringent, but Tevel can be rectified.

hebrew_text: אֶפְשָׁר בְּחוּלִּין — פְּשִׁיטָא? לָא צְרִיכָא, בְּשַׁבָּת.
human_translation: it is possible with non-sacred obvious No, necessary on Shabbat,
llm_translation: It is possible with mundane matters - is it obvious? It is not necessary, on Shabbat.

hebrew_text: בְּשַׁבָּת נָמֵי, פְּשִׁיטָא — טִלְטוּל מִדְּרַבָּנַן הוּא! הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — בְּעָצִיץ שֶׁאֵינוֹ נָקוּב, דְּרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: to Shabbat also obvious, moving, by rabbinic With what are we dealing here? an imperforate container, by rabbinic
llm_translation: On Shabbat, it is obvious - it is a handling by the Rabbis! Here, what are we dealing with - with an unperforated flowerpot, of the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: מָר סָבַר טֶבֶל חָמוּר, וּמַר סָבַר תְּרוּמָה חֲמוּרָה.
human_translation: One Sage, holds that untithed produce is more severe, and one Sage, holds that teruma is more severe.
llm_translation: Mar thought tevel is stringent, and Mar thought terumah is more stringent.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא תַּנָּאֵי הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: מִי שֶׁנְּשָׁכוֹ נָחָשׁ — קוֹרִין לוֹ רוֹפֵא מִמָּקוֹם לְמָקוֹם, וּמְקָרְעִין לוֹ אֶת הַתַּרְנְגוֹלֶת, וְגוֹזְזִין לוֹ אֶת הַכְּרֵישִׁין, וּמַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לְעַשֵּׂר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: לֹא יֹאכַל עַד שֶׁיְּעַשֵּׂר.
human_translation: Let us say is tanna’im , as it was taught one whom a snake bit one calls a doctor for him from place to another; and one tears a chicken apart for him and one harvests leeks and feeds him and one need not separate tithes; the statement of Rabbi Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: He should not eat it unless it has been tithed.
llm_translation: Let us say it is taught. As it was taught: One who was bitten by a snake — they read for him a healing from place to place, and they tear for him the rooster comb, and they cut for him the leeches, and they feed him, and there is no need to tithe, the words of Rabbi. Rabbi Elazar son of Rabbi Shimon says: He should not eat until he tithes.

hebrew_text: נֵימָא רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא, וְלָא רַבִּי!
human_translation: Let us say Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon. And not Rabbi
llm_translation: It is said: Neima, Rabbi Elazar son of Rabbi Shimon, she is, and not Rabbi!

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי, עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי הָתָם — אֶלָּא לְעִנְיַן מַעְשַׂר יָרָק דְּרַבָּנַן, אֲבָל בְּמַעְשַׂר דָּגָן דְּטֶבֶל דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הוּא, אֲפִילּוּ רַבִּי מוֹדֶה, דְּאִי שָׁרֵית לֵיהּ בְּעָצִיץ שֶׁאֵינוֹ נָקוּב — אָתֵי לְמֵיכַל בְּעָצִיץ שֶׁהוּא נָקוּב.
human_translation: Even if you say Rabbi Rabbi is saying only there, with regard to tithe from vegetables, which is rabbinic However, tithe of grains, untithed produce by Torah even Rabbi concedes Because if it is permitted for him an imperforate container, come to eat a perforated pot,
llm_translation: Even if you say "Rabbi," until here Rabbi did not say there - rather regarding the matter of the tithe of vegetables of the Rabbis, but regarding the tithe of grain that is tevel by Torah law, even if Rabbi agrees, that if you permitted it in an unperforated vessel - it will come to be eaten in a perforated vessel.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן מִי: שֶׁאֲחָזוֹ בּוּלְמוּס — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ דְּבַשׁ וְכׇל מִינֵי מְתִיקָה, שֶׁהַדְּבַשׁ וְכׇל מִינֵי מְתִיקָה מְאִירִין מְאוֹר עֵינָיו שֶׁל אָדָם. וְאַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין רְאָיָה לַדָּבָר, זֵכֶר לַדָּבָר: ״רְאוּ נָא כִּי אוֹרוּ עֵינַי כִּי טָעַמְתִּי מְעַט דְּבַשׁ הַזֶּה״.
human_translation: The Sages taught one who is seized with bulmos , one feeds him honey and all types of sweet as the honey and all types of sweet restore the sight of his eyes. And although there is no proof for the matter, there is an allusion to the matter. “See, I pray you, how my eyes are brightened because I tasted a little of this honey”
llm_translation: The sages taught: Who has a headache - they feed him bulmus, they feed him honey and all kinds of sweet things, for honey and all kinds of sweet things illuminate the eyes of a person. And even though there is no proof for this matter, a remembrance to the matter: "See now that his eyes are bright because I have tasted a little of this honey."

hebrew_text: וּמַאי: ״אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין רְאָיָה לַדָּבָר״! דְּהָתָם לָאו בּוּלְמוּס אַחְזֵיה.
human_translation: And why Although there is no proof for the matter, There, not seized with bulmos ,
llm_translation: And what is the meaning of "even though there is no visible evidence for the matter"? There, it is not in the case of Bulmus that he holds.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לֹא שָׁנוּ, אֶלָּא לְאַחַר אֲכִילָה, אֲבָל קוֹדֶם אֲכִילָה מִגְרָר גָּרֵיר, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּמְצְאוּ אִישׁ מִצְרִי בַּשָּׂדֶה וַיִּקְחוּ אוֹתוֹ אֶל דָּוִד וַיִּתְּנוּ לוֹ לֶחֶם וַיֹּאכַל וַיַּשְׁקוּהוּ מָיִם. וַיִּתְּנוּ לוֹ פֶלַח דְּבֵילָה וּשְׁנֵי צִמּוּקִים וַיֹּאכַל וַתָּשׇׁב רוּחוֹ אֵלָיו כִּי לֹא אָכַל לֶחֶם וְלֹא שָׁתָה מַיִם שְׁלֹשָׁה יָמִים וּשְׁלֹשָׁה לֵילוֹת״.
human_translation: Abaye said: They taught only after eating but before eating it whets as it is written: “And they found an Egyptian man in the field, and brought him to David, and they gave him bread and he ate, and they gave him water to drink; and they gave him a piece of a cake of figs, and two clusters of raisins, and he ate, and his spirit was restored; for he had eaten no bread nor drunk any water for three days and three nights”
llm_translation: Abaye said: They did not teach this except for after eating, but before eating one should drag the food, as it is written: "And they found an Egyptian man in the field, and they brought him to David, and they gave him bread, and he ate, and they gave him water to drink. And they gave him a piece of a cake of figs and two clusters of raisins, and he ate, and his spirit returned to him, for he had not eaten bread or drunk water for three days and three nights."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: מִי שֶׁאֲחָזוֹ בּוּלְמוּס — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ אַלְיָה בִּדְבַשׁ. רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אָמַר: אַף סוֹלֶת נְקִיָּה בִּדְבַשׁ. רַב פָּפָּא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ קִמְחָא דִשְׂעָרֵי בְּדוּבְשָׁא. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: פַּעַם אַחַת אֲחָזַנִי בּוּלְמוּס וְרַצְתִּי לְמִזְרָחָהּ שֶׁל תְּאֵנָה, וְקִיַּימְתִּי בְּעַצְמִי: ״הַחׇכְמָה תְּחַיֶּה בְעָלֶיהָ״. דְּתָנֵי רַב יוֹסֵף: הָרוֹצֶה לִטְעוֹם טַעַם תְּאֵנָה — יִפְנֶה לְמִזְרָחָהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּמִמֶּגֶד תְּבוּאוֹת שָׁמֶשׁ״.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said Shmuel said: one who is seized with bulmos , one feeds him a sheep’s tail with honey, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Also, fine wheat flour with honey Rav Pappa said: Even barley flour with honey Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Once I was seized with bulmos and I ran to the east side of a fig tree And I fulfilled “Wisdom preserves the lives of those who have it” As Rav Yosef taught: One who wishes to taste the flavor of the fig should turn to the east, as it is stated: “And for the precious things of the sun’s fruits”
llm_translation: Rav Nahman said in the name of Shmuel: One who has eaten garlic - they should feed him a leaf of the caper bush with honey. Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Also clean flour with honey. Rav Papa said: Even barley flour with honey. Rabbi Yochanan said: Once I ate caper bush and I wanted the taste of a fig, and I was fulfilled in myself: "Wisdom will give life to its possessors." As Rav Yosef taught: One who desires to taste the taste of a fig - should turn to its east side, as it is said: "And from the precious produce of the sun."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הֲווֹ קָא אָזְלִי בְּאוֹרְחָא. אַחְזֵיה בּוּלְמוּס לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, קַפְּחֵיהּ לְרוֹעֶה אַכְלֵיהּ לְרִיפְתָּא. אָמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: קִפַּחְתָּ אֶת הָרוֹעֶה. כִּי מְטוֹ לְמָתָא, אַחְזֵיה בּוּלְמוּס לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי. אַהְדְּרוּהוּ בְּלָגֵי וְצָעֵי, אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: אֲנִי קִפַּחְתִּי אֶת הָרוֹעֶה, וְאַתָּה קִפַּחְתָּ אֶת הָעִיר כּוּלָּהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei were walking on the road Rabbi Yehuda was seized with bulmos . He overpowered shepherd and ate the bread Rabbi Yosei said to him: You have robbed that shepherd. When they reached the city, Rabbi Yosei was seized with bulmos , surrounded him with jugs [ lagei ] and plates Rabbi Yehuda said to him I robbed the shepherd, but you have robbed the entire city.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehudah and Rabbi Yosei were walking on the road. A bulmus caught Rabbi Yehudah, he grabbed it for Rabbi Yehudah, he opened it for Rabbi Yosei. Rabbi Yosei said to him: "You grabbed the shepherd." When they arrived at the city, a bulmus caught Rabbi Yosei. They returned it to its place, Rabbi Yehudah said to him: "I grabbed the shepherd, and you grabbed the entire city."

hebrew_text: וְתוּ: רַבִּי מֵאִיר וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הֲווֹ קָא אָזְלִי בְּאוֹרְחָא, רַבִּי מֵאִיר הֲוָה דָּיֵיק בִּשְׁמָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי לָא הֲווֹ דָּיְיקִי בִּשְׁמָא. כִּי מְטוֹ לְהָהוּא דּוּכְתָּא, בְּעוֹ אוּשְׁפִּיזָא. יְהַבוּ לְהוּ. אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ: מָה שְׁמָךְ? אֲמַר לְהוּ: ״כִּידוֹר״. אֲמַר: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ אָדָם רָשָׁע הוּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי דוֹר תַּהְפּוּכוֹת הֵמָּה״. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אַשְׁלִימוּ לֵיהּ כִּיסַיְיהוּ. רַבִּי מֵאִיר לָא אַשְׁלֵים לֵיהּ כִּיסֵיהּ, אֲזַל אוֹתְבֵיהּ בֵּי קִיבְרֵיהּ דַּאֲבוּהּ.
human_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei were walking on the road Rabbi Meir would analyze names Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei were not analyze names. When they came to a certain place, they looked for lodging were given They said What is your name? He said to them: Kidor. said learn from this that he is a wicked person, as it is stated: “For they are a generation [ ki dor ] of upheavals” Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei entrusted their purses to him. Rabbi Meir did not entrust his purse to him went and placed it at the grave of the innkeeper’s father.
llm_translation: And further: Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei were walking on the road, Rabbi Meir was precise in his name, Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei were not precise in their names. When they came to a certain place, they asked him, "What is your name?" He said to them, "Kidor." He said: "Hear from it that he is a wicked man, as it is stated: 'For they are a generation of reversals.'" Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei handed him their purses. Rabbi Meir did not hand him his purse, he went and sat in the cemetery of his father.

hebrew_text: אִתְחֲזִי לֵיהּ בְּחֶלְמֵיהּ: תָּא שְׁקֵיל כִּיסָא דְּמַנַּח אַרֵישָׁא דְּהָהוּא גַּבְרָא. לִמְחַר אֲמַר לְהוּ: הָכִי אִתְחֲזִי לִי בְּחֶלְמַאי. אָמְרִי לֵיהּ: חֶלְמָא דְּבֵי שִׁמְשֵׁי לֵית בְּהוּ מַמָּשָׁא, אֲזַל רַבִּי מֵאִיר וְנַטְרֵיהּ כּוּלֵּי יוֹמָא וְאַיְּיתְיֵהּ.
human_translation: appeared in a dream Go take the purse placed at the head of that man, The following day, he said This appeared to me in my dream. They said to him: Dreams during twilight have no substance Rabbi Meir went and guarded all day and took it.
llm_translation: He saw him in his dreams: Take a purse of money and place it at the head of that man. The next day he said to them: This is what I saw in my dreams. They said to him: The dreams of those who eat at the house of Shimshei have no substance. Rabbi Meir went and watched him all day, and brought him.

hebrew_text: לִמְחַר אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ: הַב לַן כִּיסַן. אֲמַר לְהוּ: לֹא הָיוּ דְבָרִים מֵעוֹלָם. אֲמַר לְהוּ רַבִּי מֵאִיר: אַמַּאי לָא דָּיְיקִיתוּ בִּשְׁמָא? אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ: אַמַּאי לָא אֲמַרְתְּ לַן מָר? אֲמַר לְהוּ: אֵימַר דַּאֲמַרִי אֲנָא חֲשָׁשָׁא, אַחְזוֹקֵי מִי אֲמַרִי?
human_translation: The next day, said to Give us our purses. He said to them: These matters never occurred; Rabbi Meir said to them: Why didn’t you analyze his name They said to him: Why didn’t the Master tell us? He said to them: I said one should be suspicious, but have I said should be established as
llm_translation: Talmudic text: The next day they said to him: "Bring the basket." He said to them: "These matters were never." Rabbi Meir said to them: "Why did you not inquire in the name?" They said to him: "Why did you not tell us, master?" He said to them: "Say that I said, 'I am concerned, who will say?'"

hebrew_text: מַשְׁכוּהוּ וְעַיְּילוּהוּ לַחֲנוּתָא, חֲזוֹ טְלָפְחֵי אַשְּׂפָמֵיהּ, אֲזַלוּ וִיהַבוּ סִימָנָא לִדְבֵיתְהוּ וְשַׁקְלוּהּ לְכִיסַיְיהוּ וְאַיְיתוֹ. אֲזַל אִיהוּ וְקַטְלֵיהּ לְאִיתְּתֵיהּ.
human_translation: They dragged and brought him to a store they saw lentils on his mustache, They went and gave this sign to his wife. And they took their purses He went and killed his wife
llm_translation: Drag him and bring him to the inn, they saw the footprints of his horse, they went and gave a sign to his household, and they took it and put it in their pockets and brought it. He went and killed his wife.

hebrew_text: הַיְינוּ (דִּתְנַן): מַיִם רִאשׁוֹנִים הֶאֱכִילוּ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר. מַיִם אַחֲרוֹנִים הָרְגוּ אֶת הַנֶּפֶשׁ.
human_translation: This is as we learned the first washing, they fed pork. the final washing, to kill the person.
llm_translation: This is (as we learned): the first waters fed the pig's flesh. The latter waters killed the soul.

hebrew_text: וּלְבַסּוֹף הֲווֹ דָּיְיקִי בִּשְׁמָא. כִּי מְטוֹ לְהָהוּא בֵּיתָא דִּשְׁמֵיהּ ״בָּלָה״, לָא עֲיַילוּ לְגַבֵּיהּ. אָמְרִי: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ רָשָׁע הוּא. דִּכְתִיב: ״וָאֹמַר לַבָּלָה נִאוּפִים״, (כְּמוֹ: ״אַחֲרֵי בְלוֹתִי הָיְתָה לִּי עֶדְנָה״, כְּלוֹמַר: זָקְנָה בְּנִאוּפִים).
human_translation: And in the end, they would analyze names. When they came to a house of named Bala, they did not enter. They said: Conclude from here that he is wicked, as it is written: “I said of her who was worn out [ bala ] by adulteries” as “After I am grown old [ beloti ] shall I have pleasure?” aged through adulteries.
llm_translation: At the end, they were precise in his name. When they came to that house whose name is "Balah," they did not enter it. They said: Conclude from this that he is wicked. As it is written: "And I said to the worn-out one, 'Be lively!'" (Like saying: "After my withering, I had a time," meaning: she became old in adulteries).

hebrew_text: מִי שֶׁנְּשָׁכוֹ כֶּלֶב שׁוֹטֶה וְכוּ׳. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן, חֲמִשָּׁה דְּבָרִים נֶאֶמְרוּ בְּכֶלֶב שׁוֹטֶה: פִּיו פָּתוּחַ, וְרִירוֹ נוֹטֵף, וְאׇזְנָיו סְרוּחוֹת, וּזְנָבוֹ מוּנָּח עַל יַרְכוֹתָיו, וּמְהַלֵּךְ בְּצִידֵּי דְּרָכִים. וְיֵשׁ אוֹמְרִים: אַף נוֹבֵחַ וְאֵין קוֹלוֹ נִשְׁמָע. מִמַּאי הָוֵי? רַב אָמַר: נָשִׁים כַּשְׁפָנִיּוֹת מְשַׂחֲקוֹת בּוֹ, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: רוּחַ רָעָה שׁוֹרָה עָלָיו.
human_translation: one whom a mad dog bit, The Sages taught Five signs were said about a mad dog: Its mouth is open; and its saliva drips; and its ears are floppy its tail rests on its legs; and it walks on the edges of roads. And some say it also barks and its voice is not heard. From where did Rav said: Witches play with it And Shmuel said: An evil spirit rests upon it.
llm_translation: The one who was bitten by a mad dog, etc. The Rabbis taught: Five things were said regarding a mad dog: Its mouth is open, its saliva drips, its ears are hanging, its tail is placed between its hind legs, and it walks on the sides of roads. And some say: It also barks but its voice is not heard. What is the reason? Rav said: Women jest at him like hyenas, and Shmuel said: An evil spirit rules over him.

hebrew_text: מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ? אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ
human_translation: What is between these There is between them
llm_translation: What is the difference between them? There is a difference between them.

hebrew_text: לְמִקְטְלֵיהּ בְּדָבָר הַנִּזְרָק.
human_translation: killing it with an object that is thrown
llm_translation: To kill him with a thrown object.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דִּשְׁמוּאֵל. כְּשֶׁהוֹרְגִין אוֹתוֹ — אֵין הוֹרְגִין אוֹתוֹ אֶלָּא בְּדָבָר הַנִּזְרָק. דְּחָיֵיף בֵּיהּ — מִסְתַּכַּן, דְּנָכֵית לֵיהּ — מָיֵית. דְּחָיֵיף בֵּיהּ — מִסְתַּכַּן: מַאי תַּקַּנְתֵּיהּ? נִישַׁלַּח מָאנֵיהּ וְנִירְהַיט. רַב הוּנָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ חַף בֵּיהּ חַד מִינַּיְיהוּ בְּשׁוּקָא, שַׁלְּחִינְהוּ לְמָאנֵיהּ וְרָהֵיט. אֲמַר: קִיַּימְתִּי בְּעַצְמִי ״הַחׇכְמָה תְּחַיֶּה בְעָלֶיהָ״.
human_translation: was taught in accordance with Shmuel: When one kills he should kill it only with a thrown object. one who is rubbed by a mad dog will become dangerously one bitten will die. What is the remedy one who is rubbed by mad dog becomes dangerously ill? Let him take off his clothing and run. Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, was rubbed by one of these in the market, he took off his clothing and ran. He said: I have fulfilled “Wisdom preserves the lives of those who have it”
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Shmuel: When they are killing him — they only kill him with something that is thrown. If he strengthens himself — he is supported, if he weakens — he is killed. If he strengthens himself — he is supported. What is the remedy for him? They send him to his place and stone him. Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, found one of them in the market, sent him to his place, and stoned him. He said: I have fulfilled in myself, "Wisdom will give life to those who possess it."

hebrew_text: דְּנָכֵית לֵיהּ מָיֵית: מַאי תַּקַּנְתֵּיהּ? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: נֵיתֵי מַשְׁכָּא דְּאַפָּא דִּיכְרָא וְנִיכְתּוֹב עֲלֵיהּ: אֲנָא פְּלָנְיָא בַּר פְּלָנִיתָא אַמַּשְׁכָּא דְּאַפָּא דִּיכְרָא כָּתֵיבְנָא עֲלָךְ: ״כַּנְתִּי כַּנְתִּי קְלֵירוֹס״. וְאָמְרִי לַהּ: ״קַנְדִּי קַנְדִּי קְלוֹרוֹס, יָהּ יָהּ ה׳ צְבָאוֹת אָמֵן אָמֵן סֶלָה״. וְנִשְׁלְחִינְהוּ לְמָאנֵיהּ וְלִקְבְּרִינְהוּ בֵּי קִבְרֵי עַד תְּרֵיסַר יַרְחֵי שַׁתָּא, וְנַפְּקִינְהוּ וְנִקְלִינְהוּ בְּתַנּוּרָא וּנְבַדְּרִינְהוּ לְקִטְמֵיהּ אַפָּרָשַׁת דְּרָכִים. וְהָנָךְ תְּרֵיסַר יַרְחֵי שַׁתָּא, כִּי שָׁתֵי מַיָּא — לָא לִישְׁתֵּי אֶלָּא בְּגוּבְתָּא דִנְחָשָׁא, דִּילְמָא חָזֵי בָּבוּאָה דְּשֵׁידָא וְלִיסְתַּכַּן. כִּי הָא דְּאַבָּא בַּר מָרְתָא הוּא אַבָּא בַּר מִנְיוֹמֵי, עֲבַדָא לֵיהּ אִימֵּיהּ גּוּבְתָּא דְּדַהֲבָא.
human_translation: One bitten will die. What is the remedy? Abaye said: Let him bring the skin of a male hyena and write on it: I, so-and-so, son of so-and-so, am writing about you upon the skin of a male hyena: Kanti kanti kelirus . And some say Kandi kandi keloros . Yah , Yah , Lord of Hosts, amen amen Selah. And let him take off his clothes and bury them in a cemetery for twelve months the year, he should take them out, and burn them in an oven, and scatter the ashes at a crossroads. And those twelve months the year, when he drinks water, let him drink only from a copper tube lest he see the demon in the water and be endangered, like Abba bar Marta, who is Abba bar Manyumi, whose mother made him a gold tube
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "denakheit lei mayeit: mai takanteih? amar Abbayei: neitei mashka de'apa dikhra ve'nichtov aleih: ana pelanyaa bar pelanita amashka de'apa dikhra kateivna aleikh: 'kaniti kaniti k'leiros'. ve'amar lei: 'kandi kandi k'loros, Yah Yah Hashem Tzevaot amen amen selah'. ve'nishlekhinhu lemanei ve'likberinhu bei kivrei ad treisar yarchei shata, ve'nafekinhu ve'niklinhu betanura unvadrinhu lekitmeih apparashat drakhim. ve'hankh treisar yarchei shata, ki shatei maya — la lishbei ela beguvta dinchasha, dilma hazey bavua de'sheida velishtakhan. ki ha de'Abba bar Marta hu Abba bar Minyomei, avada lei immeih guvta de'dahava." English translation: "He examined it and found it to be dead. What is its remedy? Abbayei said: Let a mixture of ground-up aphid and wine be placed on it. I, so-and-so son of so-and-so, had a mixture of ground-up aphid written on me. 'I have acquired, I have acquired a palace.' And some say: 'I have acquired, I have acquired a palace, Yah Yah, Hashem Tzevaot, amen amen selah.' They were then sent to his place and buried in the graves of the righteous until the fifteenth of the month of Adar, and they were taken out and burned in an oven and their ashes scattered in the pathways. And during those fifteen days, when there are two waters, one should not drink except from a golden tube, lest he see the entrance of a demon and be harmed. For this is what Abba bar Marta, who is Abba bar Minyomei, did for his mother, he made for her a golden tube."

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד אָמַר רַבִּי מַתְיָא: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן חָשׁ בְּצַפְדִּינָא. אֲזַל גַּבַּהּ דְּהַהִיא מַטְרוֹנִיתָא, עֲבַדָא לֵיהּ מִלְּתָא חַמְשָׁא וּמַעֲלֵי שַׁבְּתָא. אֲמַר לַהּ: בְּשַׁבָּת מַאי? אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: לָא צְרִיכַתְּ. אִי מִצְטְרִיכְנָא מַאי? אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: אִישְׁתְּבַע לִי דְּלָא מְגַלֵּית, אִישְׁתְּבַע: לֵאלָהָא דְיִשְׂרָאֵל לָא מְגַלֵּינָא. נְפַק דַּרְשַׁהּ בְּפִירְקָא.
human_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Matya said: Rabbi Yoḥanan suffered tzefidna , He went to a certain matron [ matronita ] She prepared a medicine for him on Thursday and Friday. He said to her: What on Shabbat, She said to him: You will not need If I do need what She said to him: Swear to me that you will not reveal He swore: To the God of the Jews, I will not reveal it. went out and taught it publicly,
llm_translation: And furthermore, Rabbi Matya said: Rabbi Yochanan was diligent in Tzafdinah. He went up to the roof of that attic, did a matter of five and went up on Shabbat. He said to her: On Shabbat, what? She said to him: You do not need. If we need, what? She said to him: I demand that you do not reveal, I demand: By the God of Israel, I do not reveal. He went out and expounded in the study hall.

hebrew_text: וְהָא אִישְׁתְּבַע לַהּ! לֵאלָהָא דְיִשְׂרָאֵל לָא מְגַלֵּינָא. הָא לְעַמּוֹ יִשְׂרָאֵל — מְגַלֵּינָא. וְהָא אִיכָּא חִלּוּל הַשֵּׁם! דִּמְגַלֵּי לַהּ מֵעִיקָּרָא.
human_translation: But he swore to her I will not reveal it to the God of the Jews. I will reveal it to His people, the Jews. Still, there is a desecration of God’s name, He revealed to her at the outset.
llm_translation: And he claimed against her! By the God of Israel we do not reveal. This for his nation, Israel — we reveal. And there is a desecration of the Name! For it is revealed to her from the beginning.

hebrew_text: מַאי עֲבַדָא לֵיהּ? אָמַר רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אַמֵּי: מֵי שְׂאוֹר, שֶׁמֶן זַיִת, וָמֶלַח. רַב יֵימַר אֲמַר: שְׂאוֹר גּוּפֵיהּ, שֶׁמֶן זַיִת, וָמֶלַח. רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: מִשְׁחָא דְּגַדְפָּא דַאֲווֹזָא. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: אֲנָא עֲבַדִי לְכוּלְּהוּ וְלָא אִיתַּסַּאי, עַד דַּאֲמַר לִי הַהוּא טַיָּיעָא: אַיְיתִי קַשְׁיָיתָא דְזֵיתָא דְּלָא מְלוֹ תִּילְתָּא, וּקְלִינְהוּ בְּנוּרָא אַמָּרָא חַדְתָּא, וְאַדְבֵּיק בְּכַכֵּי דָרֵיה. עֲבַדִי הָכִי וְאִיתַּסַּאי.
human_translation: What she prepared for him? Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ami, said: water leaven olive oil, and salt. Rav Yeimar said: leaven itself, olive oil, and salt. Rav Ashi said: fat a goose’s wing. Abaye said: I made all of these and was not cured until a certain Arab told me Take olive seeds that are less than one-third and burn them in a fire on top of a new hoe, and stick them along the row of gums. I did this and was cured.
llm_translation: What did he do with it? Rav Ahah son of Rav Ammi said: Water, barley flour, and salt. Rav Yeimar said: Barley flour itself, olive oil, and salt. Rav Ashei said: The vinegar of pickled capers. Abbaye said: I did all of them and did not find relief until that old man told me: Bring me a basket of unripe olives, and roast them in a pan, then grind them and place them on the opening of his ear. I did so, and found relief.

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי הֲוָה? מֵחַמִּימֵי חַמִּימֵי דְּחִיטֵּי, וּמִשִּׁיּוּרֵי כָּסָא דְהַרְסָנָא. וּמַאי סִימָנֵיהּ — כַּד רָמֵי מִידֵּי בְּכַכֵּיהּ וְאָתֵא דְּמָא מִבֵּי דָרֵי. רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן כִּי חָשׁ בְּצַפְדִּינָא, עֲבַד הָכִי בְּשַׁבְּתָא וְאִיתַּסִּי. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הֵיכִי עָבֵיד הָכִי? אֲמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: שָׁאנֵי צַפְדִּינָא הוֹאִיל וּמַתְחִיל בַּפֶּה, וְגוֹמֵר בִּבְנֵי מֵעַיִים.
human_translation: From where this wheat bread that is too hot and fish remains fried in oil. What is the sign of When one puts something between his teeth, blood comes out from his gums. When Rabbi Yoḥanan suffered from tzefidna , he prepared this on Shabbat and was cured. And how did Rabbi Yoḥanan prepare this Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Tzefidna is different, since it does begin in the mouth but it ends up in the intestines
llm_translation: From what was it? From the heat of the heat of the wheat, and from the remnants of the chair of the carpenter. And what is its sign? - Like one who throws from his hand into his lap, and comes out blood from the house of the carpenter. Rabbi Yochanan, when he felt a headache, would do so on Shabbat and be healed. And how did Rabbi Yochanan do so? Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: The headache is different because he starts with the mouth and finishes with the intestines.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כְּמַאן — כְּרַבִּי מַתְיָא בֶּן חָרָשׁ, דְּאָמַר: הַחוֹשֵׁשׁ בְּפִיו מְטִילִין לוֹ סַם בְּשַׁבָּת. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹמֵר בְּזוֹ, וְלֹא בְּאַחֶרֶת.
human_translation: Rav Ḥiyya bar Abba said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: In accordance with whose Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash, who said: one who suffers pain in his mouth, one puts medicine in his on Shabbat, said to him: but I say in this but no other.
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Chiya bar Abba said to Rabbi Yochanan: Like whom? Like Rabbi Matya ben Charash, who said: One who is concerned about his mouth, they may place medicine in it on Shabbat. He said to him: I say this specifically, and not in general.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ: מִי שֶׁאֲחָזוֹ יֵרָקוֹן — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲמוֹר, מִי שֶׁנְּשָׁכוֹ כֶּלֶב שׁוֹטֶה — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ מֵחֲצַר כָּבֵד שֶׁלּוֹ, וְהַחוֹשֵׁשׁ בְּפִיו — מְטִילִין לוֹ סַם בְּשַׁבָּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מַתְיָא בֶּן חָרָשׁ. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בְּאֵילּוּ אֵין בָּהֶם מִשּׁוּם רְפוּאָה. ״בְּאֵלּוּ״ לְמַעוֹטֵי מַאי? מַאי לָאו, לְמַעוֹטֵי סַם?
human_translation: Let us say that supports him: one who is seized with yerakon , one feeds him donkey meat one whom a mad dog bit, one feeds him the lobe of its liver; one who has pain in his mouth, one puts medicine in his on Shabbat; this is the statement of Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash. And the Rabbis say: These have no as a remedy. these, to exclude what? What, is it not to exclude medicine
llm_translation: Let us say it assists him: one who was bitten by a snake - they feed him donkey meat; one who was bitten by a mad dog - they feed him the liver of his courtyard, and one who is concerned about his mouth - they place a spice in his mouth on Shabbat, the words of Rabbi Matya ben Charash. And the sages say: in which cases do they not have the status of healing? "In which cases" to exclude what? To exclude spice?

hebrew_text: לָא, לְמַעוֹטֵי: מַקִּיזִין דָּם לִסְרוֹנְכֵי. הָכִי נָמֵי מִסְתַּבְּרָא. דְּתַנְיָא: שְׁלֹשָׁה דְּבָרִים אָמַר רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי שֶׁשָּׁמַע מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מַתְיָא בֶּן חָרָשׁ: מַקִּיזִין דָּם לִסְרוֹנְכֵי בְּשַׁבָּת, וּמִי שֶׁנְּשָׁכוֹ כֶּלֶב שׁוֹטֶה — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ מֵחֲצַר כָּבֵד שֶׁלּוֹ, וְהַחוֹשֵׁשׁ בְּפִיו מְטִילִין לוֹ סַם בְּשַׁבָּת.
human_translation: No, it excludes Bloodletting serunkhi So too, this is reasonable as it was taught Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said three things that he heard in the name of Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash: One let blood for serunkhi on Shabbat; and one whom a mad dog bit, one feeds him the lobe of its liver; and one who has pain in his mouth, one puts medicine in his on Shabbat.
llm_translation: Not for, for the purpose of: they pierce blood for the seronkhei. So it was said and it is logical. As it was taught: Three things Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said in the name of Rabbi Matya ben Charash: They pierce blood for the seronkhei on Shabbat, and one who is bitten by a mad dog - they feed him from his liver, and they are concerned about his mouth, they place medicine in it on Shabbat.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בְּאֵילּוּ אֵין בָּהֶן מִשּׁוּם רְפוּאָה. ״בְּאֵילּוּ״ לְמַעוֹטֵי מַאי? מַאי לָאו, אַתַּרְתֵּי בָּתְרָיָיתָא וּלְמַעוֹטֵי דְּרֵישָׁא! לָא: אַתַּרְתֵּי דְּרֵישָׁא קַמָּיָיתָא, וּלְמַעוֹטֵי דְּסֵיפָא.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: These have no as a remedy. these to exclude what? What, is it not the latter two to exclude the first No, to the first two first and excludes the latter clause
llm_translation: The sages say: In which cases is there no healing. "In which cases" - to exclude what? What is it not? You have placed it at the end and to exclude the beginning! No, you have placed it at the beginning and to exclude the end.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּתָנֵי רַבָּה בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל: עוּבָּרָה שֶׁהֵרִיחָה — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתָהּ עַד שֶׁתָּשׁוּב נַפְשָׁהּ, וּמִי שֶׁנְּשָׁכוֹ כֶּלֶב שׁוֹטֶה — מַאֲכִילִין אוֹתוֹ מֵחֲצַר כָּבֵד שֶׁלּוֹ, וְהַחוֹשֵׁשׁ בְּפִיו — מְטִילִין לוֹ סַם בְּשַׁבָּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, שֶׁאָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מַתְיָא בֶּן חָרָשׁ. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בָּזוֹ וְלֹא בְּאַחֶרֶת. ״בְּזוֹ״ אַהֵיָיא? אִילֵּימָא אַעוּבָּרָה, פְּשִׁיטָא! עוּבָּרָה מִי אִיכָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר דְּלָא? אֶלָּא לָאו — אַסַּם. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Come hear as Rabba bar Shmuel taught a pregnant woman who smells one feeds her until she is satisfied, and one whom a mad dog bit, one feeds him from the lobe of its liver; and one who has pain in his mouth, one places medicine in his on Shabbat; the statement of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, who said in the name of Rabbi Matya ben Ḥarash.
